awd_titl_txt: Articulating Complex Science: The Case of Sea Level Rise; Washington, District Columbia; Spring or Fall 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This project uses funds to convene a 1.5-day interdisciplinary workshop in Washington, D.C. at which scientists, lawyers, and journalists will explore differing approaches to articulating a complex science topic, such as sea level rise, within the cultural norms of their professions. 

The goals of this workshop are to: (1) identify and facilitate communication strategies that effectively convey the science of sea level rise and inform policy and legal discussions; (2) help legal experts and policymakers gain better understanding of the science of sea level rise; and (3) highlight the challenges in understanding and communicating the uncertainties of the science of sea level rise.

The Workshop uses sea-level rise as a case study because the topic is scientifically complex and is the basis for discussions in the larger civil society regarding cause, effect, mitigation, and adaptation.  These discussions necessarily involve scientists, engineers, planners, policy makers, attorneys, and journalists.    

The Workshop conveners will develop discussion materials for use at the Workshop and disseminate these materials, along with discussion outcomes, afterwards.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With support from the National Science Foundation's (NSF) Paleoclimate Office, the Environmental Law Institute (ELI) convened a webinar and in-person workshop on Communicating Complex Science: The Challenge of Sea Level Rise. 

The convenings were designed to identify and facilitate communication strategies to effectively convey the science of sea level rise and inform policy and legal positions, help legal experts and policymakers gain better understanding of the science of sea level rise, and highlight challenges in understanding and communicating the science of sea level rise. These events involved experts from across the coastal United States, including the Pacific, Gulf of Mexico, and Atlantic coasts, resulting in a diverse set of shared perspectives, challenges, and experiences. The sessions integrated discourse from academic institutions, including law schools and scientific departments, scientific institutions, state Sea Grant offices, government agencies, non-governmental organizations, and the private sector.

The webinar on the science of sea level rise was designed to initiate dialogue in advance of the in-person workshop. The webinar featured presentations by UW-Madison's Andrea Dutton, a sea level reconstruction expert, and Climate Central CEO and Chief Scientist Ben Strauss. The focus of this session was on communicating the key aspects of sea level rise science and explaining the methodologies behind attributing real world impacts to sea level rise. 

Building on the webinar, the workshop facilitated a robust discussion of different communication strategies used within the various professions represented about best practices for communicating sea level rise science to a diverse set of audiences. It also provided an opportunity for sea level rise expert and NOAA scientist William Sweet to educate legal scholars, judges, and policymakers on the agency?s 2022 report on NOAA scenarios. Finally, the workshop concluded with the production of actionable summary documents that identified challenges and opportunities for those working in sea level rise science communication. Through these programs, ELI energized a broad array of experts to deploy newly discovered sea level rise science and communication techniques in their respective positions and communities. To accompany these events, ELI produced and distributed a document summarizing key workshop themes, takeaways, and suggestions for future work.

ELI also increased awareness of the legal issues of sea level rise among the general public through a blog (https://www.eli.org/vibrant-environment-blog/navigating-murky-waters-sea-level-rise-adaptation) and podcast (https://eli-podcast.transistor.fm/episodes/legal-and-policy-issues-of-sea-level-rise.
